snippet: World Cup security guards who are assigned to maintain order inside the throbbing stadiums must keep their eyes firmly locked on the stands, and not the soccer.
abstract: Security guards working World Cup matches are required to stand within shouting distance of the games but are not allowed to watch the games at all; should Brazil win its sixth World Cup in July, guards at the stadium may be the only two dozen people in the country not watching.

byline.original: By ANDREW KEH and SERGIO PEÇANHA
byline.contributor: Andrew Keh reported from Fortaleza, Brazil, and Sergio Peçanha from Natal.

lead_paragraph: World Cup security guards who are assigned to maintain order inside the throbbing stadiums must keep their eyes firmly locked on the stands, and not the soccer.

headline.seo: World Cup Security Is Near Soccer History, but Can’t See It
headline.main: Soccer Fans’ Dream Job Has a Catch: No Peeking
headline.print_headline: Soccer Fans’ Dream Job Has a Catch: No Peeking
